2015 vintage. Aroma of nuts, cinammon, some other spicey, juniper, some piney. Pour black with light brown head. Flavour of nuts, some fruits like strawberry, cinammon, piney bitter finish. Light, watery smooth. Medium finish, dry.
Donkerbruin. Bruine kraag. Kruidig bier met pompoen? Weinig body. Ben er niet kapot van.
Pours black with a thick, foamy white head. The aroma is spicy, sticky pine like. The taste is a spicy, cough syrup and pine. I have to say I really like this. I?d be into buying a few more of these.
Bottle. Pours a dark brownish color. Aroma and taste are spices, fruit, and some honey.

0.355 l bottle from ’De Bierkoning’, 2015 vintage (best before September 2017). Clear, very dark red to black with a thin, frothy, slowly diminishing, brown head. Sweetish, slightly roasty, fruity-malty aroma of raisins, dates, overripe banana, dark chocolate and almond. Sweetish, slightly roasty, fruity-malty taste of overripe banana, raisins, dark chocolate, coffee and nuts, followed by a short, roasty and slightly bitter finish with more dark chocolate and coffee. Medium body, slightly creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Nice winter/christmas beer, although a bit faint and not too complex.

355ml bottle as “Anchor Christmas Ale 2015” bought at The Bottle Shop in Sai Kung.



Looks: Deep blackish browncolour; One and a quarter finger head with crumpety beige foam which lasts for 90 seconds; Excellent good sticky lacing with localized slight carbonation.



Aroma: Fragrant full dark malt, with caramel, strong toffee, light plums, traces of cinnamon, cream, very light coffee, light molasses and biscuits. Spicy aroma comes through as beer warms.



Taste: Close to light sweet dark Ale malt, with roasted chestnuts, nutmeg, very light cinnamon, burnt caramel, toffee, dark fruits, light molasses, dry biscuits, yeast, lemon, light bitter hops and grass. 



Body: Mid to light body. Thin and dry palate.



Mouth Feel: Like a Porter with richer dark malt, in a watery background. Slightly burnt caramel, toffee and light fruitcake dominate, followed by apparent nutmeg and light plum. Sweetness is moderate, so does lemon wuth very dry biscuity yeast to round. Okay. 



Hoppiness: None in nose. Fair lemon and grass in taste.
Bitterness is light for a lasting, light astringent caramel malty finish.



After Taste: Very dry. Light spicy and fairly bitter to mouth.



Comments: Sounds like the spirit of Xmas means all things being light and easy, and so does this one - aroma is literally light as feather, taste is saved by very solid caramel malt with subtle nutmeg and dark fruits with bare-bone lemony hoppiness. Easy drinking alright, but I want something more exciting come Xmas. Unimpressive.



P.S. Thank you Admin for the “Saeame Street: Feist sings 1,2,3,4” video fro my #1234 ratings : )

From bottle, pours dark brown with a medium, frothy light brown head. Aromas are caramel and malt, nuts and spice. Flavors add raisin notes and more spices. Medium bodied. Honestly I was expecting more from this (based on the appearance?), almost like the alcohol should be a tick higher to give it more backbone. Still, an enjoyable colder weather brew.
Dark brown color with beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, nutty and spices. Taste of molasses and spicy.
On tap. Pours a dark cola brown, very foamy. Aroma somewhat muted, kind of a bitter, herbal note. Flavor is sweet, herbal, and piney. Palate a bit harsh. Not impressed this year.

This is one of my seasonal favorites and 2016’s ale is among the best in class. Pours dark mahogany but clear with a rich tan head. Molasses and ginger notes are strongest on the nose and palate. I five a hint of feral nose and there might be a slight umami flavour add well. Yummy...Santa, I need a case of this.

Bottle 33cl, a dark beer with good head. Nose is on toasted malt and toasted caramel, spices. Aroma is on dark caramel, licorice, burnt caramel, anise, toffee, dark lager notes, nutty, burnt spices, good.
Spicy ale which aroma hints towards amber ales. It pours a dark glass and is rather enjoyable.

Wersja 2014. Piana kremowa, drobna i trwała, ładny lejsing. Barwa mahoniowa, klarowna. Aromat słodki, głównie karmel, suszone owoce, miód i cukierki werther’s original na równym poziomie. W smaku wbrew pozorom nie jest słodko, raczej pół słodko - na podstawie z karmelu i toffi czuć anyż, koper włoski, przyprawy korzenne, kandyzowane owoce, syrop klonowy... Goryczki i alkoholu brak. Nagazowanie nieco poniżej średniego. Dość wodniste w odczuciu. 
Zbyt lekkie, zbyt rzadkie, jak na taką ilość przypraw, piwo bożonarodzeniowe. Brakuje tu słodyczy, gęstości i mocy... Dodatkowo anyż i toffi w połączeniu nie wypadają najlepiej.

Updated for 2016 bottle. Pours a dark olive brown with a low light tan head, good lacing. Spicy nose of cinnamon, clove, nutmeg matched by sweet doughy malt, a hint of anise. Lovely balanced flavour from front to back of cookie dough and spices. Nothing is fighting and it stays full, much improved over last year which was over-spiced and watery at the backend. Medium feel and very smooth over the palate. Gentle and excellent.

dark brown with a quick off white head. nose is weak and slightly spiced with a touch of brown sugar. flavor is basically a generic brown ale with a pinch of nutmeg and a little spicing. short finish. not very impressive in any way
2013. Bottle from Van Alsem. 2013. Lots of spices, piney, coffee, cocoa. A bit watery and bitter. Backlog from 2014/03/11.

Appearance: nearly solid black with only faint ruby highlights, one finger of rocky tan head, good retention and spotty lacing. (3/5) Aroma: toffee, molasses, coffee, dark chocolate and fruits, spices, woody spruce. (7/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate bitter. (7/10) Palate: medium-full slightly oily body, moderate carbonation, lingering slightly sticky finish. (4/5)

Definitely an interesting winter warmer style of brew. Lots of traditional midwinter spices and dark, molasses-y malt give it a lot of the “fruitcake in a glass” character I like to see in these ales. There’s more than a hint of spruce, which makes me think they might actually incorporate spruce tips into the brew, but it’s not overwhelming or medicinal. (14/20)
Bottle 2015. Pours black with ruby highlights and small tan head. Nose is maple, vanilla and nutmeg. Taste adds some dark fruit. Good.

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

Beer tasting @ Havregatan 151120. Bottle (355 ml) from Kihoskh, Copenhagen. [ Vintage 2006 ]. Malty and caramely with lots of dried fruits, woody with spicy and some light liquorice notes, medium sweet and a bit flat, medium body with an oily texture. The finish is dry and woody with dried fruits.

2015 edition bottle. Aroma of maple, toffee, capucino, vanilla and cinnamom and some malts. Nice dark brown colour, head vanishes fast. Flavours are a bit porterlike, but also a bit watery. Lots of cinnamom, maple and malts. Sweet, maple/toffee aftertaste. Ok for what it is.

2015 version out of bottle from brewers droop, Bristol. pours deep dark ruby with an orange brown thick persistent head. Aroma is warming with doughy spice like light cinnamon, there is an earthy character against the soft roast nature and possibly spruce notes. The flavour has a dry, nutty roast/char flavour which is balanced by a silky texture. There are subtle spice notes here. Toward the back of the tongue there is a liquorice flavour reminiscent of my early homebrew but much cleaner and later,, some doughyness is perceived in the flavour. Overall, some great flavours and certainly a multifaceted beer though i would say the dough character is somewhat overwhelming some other aspects of the beer. Very nice, though.

Pours a dark brown with ruby glints where light comes through. A large brown-khaki head forms and retains well. Prune, brown sugar, and a little coffee are noted in the nose. I like the way this drinks--a soft, moderately thick fashion. Muted sweet prune fruit, light sorghum, and some of that homebrew recipe in a box characteristic are all noted in the flavors. Reminds me of a British Porter.
Pours a dark brown almost black color. Aroma of roasted malt. Taste is slightly nutty with a good dark malt flavor. Easy drinking with a lightly dry finish.
Flaska. Dofter av kryddnejlika, malt, karamell och vörtbröd. Smakinslag av kryddnejlika, ingefära, karamell och apelsinskal. Något tunn i kroppen.

Over the years, people have put their brains and palates to work trying to figure out just what the hell Anchor’s Christmas Ale is flavored with. Enough secrets have been leaked over the years you could probably figure it out after enough time on the internet. However, it’s more fun not to know. Besides, the formula changes from year to year, anyway. The 2015 release is dark brown with shades of mahogany. It has candy notes redolent of dark fruit (especially plum), toffee, bittersweet chocolate, licorice, molasses, and spices (cinnamon & nutmeg). While this is a malty brew, I was happy to note some fresh and lightly citrusy hops. The comparison is probably cheesy, but trying to guess at Christmas Ale’s components is like shaking a holiday present and trying to figure out what’s inside the box. Shit, that was lame. I’m becoming a sentimental, foolish bastard.

Flaska från SB. Mörk rubinröd, brunsvart vätska med mörkbeieget halvt finger tjocker skum som lägger sig. Sötsur och maltig doft av russin, torr choklad, hubba-bubba tuggummi, råglimpa, pumpernickel. Även en aning lakrits, kaffe och en nypa julkryddor. Medelstor, halvtorr kropp; inleder något större för att sedan lägga sig ganska kvickt. Kanske en aning för mycket kolsyra. Ganska kraftig för sin låga alkoholhalt. Inleds med kaffe, fudge och en del mörkrostade toner - gränsar nästan till en stout! Kanske en aning ekfat och enbär. Sötman tillbakahållen i jämförelse med aromen. Efterbeskan är främst kaffe. Helt ok!

2015 bottle purchased in CO. I pick up pick up chocolate, raisin, herbal and licorice notes. I’ve been trying it since 2007 and feel this is one of my favorites. I liked the 2007 a lot and feel this is very comparable. Hard to be 100% sure without the ability to try them side by side. I’ll hunt down a case of it.

2016 bottle purchased in CO.  Pours black with tan head.  Aroma is malty herbal with hints of raison, prune and licorice.  Taste is sweet and herbal like the aroma with a bitter licorice prune finish.  I try it every year and while i like it i like the 2015 better.

Let’s split this between the 2014 and 2006 batches...cheers Craig.

2014 bottle. Pours dark brown with no head. Aroma is raisins, toffee, malts. Taste is raisins, toffee, earthy hops, dust and slight spice.

Bottle 2014 - Light brown colour, nice creamy tan head with lacing. Aroma of raisins, gingerbread, cloves, honey and some resinous hops. Nice christmas beer.

355ml bottle at Beer Station, Xiamen on 8 Sept 2015. Pours dark brown/black with an off white head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, saison type aromas, dried fruit and medicine. Taste of a little roast and toffee.

2014. Aroma is ginger, figs or some other dark fruit, nutmeg, malt. Appearance is a foggy reddish brown with a light tan head. Taste is figs, ginger, nutmeg, disappears very quickly. Mouthfeel is a decent carbonation but the flavor is very light and leaves immediately, which I suppose isn’t horrible. Overall, this beer is well past its prime yet somehow I doubt I would enjoy it more fresh.

12oz bottle dated 2014. Finings-laden dark mahogany color, low tan foam. Sweet spice nose. Nutmeg, pine resin, cinnamon, raisin, clove, toasted wood & more notes in the tongue. Full- body and medium+ carbonation.
355ml bottle at home, from Appellation Wines, Dalry Road, Edinburgh, spicy, toffee aroma, brown, thin bubbly beige head, no lacing, sweet spicy, malty, viscous
12oz bottle shared with mr_h. Almost black, big foamy head. Leafy treacle aroma. Flavour of cinnamon and other spices. Sour aftertaste. Not my sort of beer.

2013 Version- Pours a very dark brown mahogany color with a thick tan head on top. Smells of mellow spiced fruit, toffee, molasses, pine resin, and gingerbread. Dry, spiced, somewhat gingerbread-y flavor. A little tart fruit, spruce, bitter chocolate, orange peel, and faint maple. Medium body, creamy texture, with a slickness that sticks to the tongue. Definitely better as it warms up.

Light brown lasting foam and a delicate aroma of fig, plum and roasted malt. The taste varies over hard roasted malt, a little hazelnut, fig, dried dark fruit (prune / raisin) candied and dark bitter chocolate. It is without doubt a very delicious ale with clearly Belgian touch. It signals Christmas with large ’C’ and tastes determined by more than 5.5% alcohol as the label says. The bitterness is gentle, yet present, and put a beautiful end to the many flavors that bombards the taste buds to a degree almost become too violent. Now one should not complain when a brewmaster pampers with all its artist, but less hard roasted malt, less heavy fruit hues and easier fullness had also dressed this great ale. Semi-dry aftertaste.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass.
Aroma- Malt and spices, real pleasing
Appearance- A reddish-black with a small off-white head
Taste- Once again the malt and spices are present. this time they are in the flavor and they deliver: very nice

Overall- An excellent version of a winter warmer

355ml bottle v2012. Dark brown color with light beige head. Malty aroma, spicy, nutmeg, some cinnamon, dark dried fruits, light chocolate and licorice, caramel. Sweet and light bitter taste like aroma. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

2014 bottle, deep brown beer, good almond head, good lace. Aroma cinnamon, raisin, molasses, coffee. Taste is cinnamon, rootbeer, coffee, cloves. Palate a little light, but ok, carbonation nicely subdued. This should be mulled, I think, or done as a flip.

355ml bottle from 2014, still available at Systembolaget Söderhallarna. Dark brown with a creamy, compact, tan head. 2014 Bottle: This one pours a cloudy, dark amber color. There was a finger of a light tan head. Some lacing. Good nose. Malts, holiday spices are the most predominate. Getting some dark fruits also. The taste is very good. Very rich malt body, with just a bit of sweetness, Subdues holiday spices, maybe some orange, a touch of earthy hops. Very Nice!
2014 version. On draft and the 2 L bottle. Dark brown with one finger head. Aroma of pine, spices (nut meg). Really well done and different from the more cinnamon christmas beers.
Old rating. Enjoy this one when I get it round the season. Dark tan. Pine, vanilla, earth, clove, spices. Medium bodied and not overly spiced.

Backlog, Christmas 2014. Bottle. Dark brown with two finger tan head, dissipates quickly leaving some lacings. Wonderful aroma of pine needles, vanilla, spices, liquorice, malt. Taste about the same with a dry finish. Medium body, light to medium carbo.

This is an ale I look forward to every year. This is dark and malty and perfect in the cold. This is great looking and smells amazing.

12oz bottle from Masuyo’s Liquor in Asagaya. Poured into a shaker pint. Deep rich brown color (almost black) with a nice tan medium-sized head. Starts out slightly sweet on the palate then swings toward a sticky, dry finish with the resiny flavors and cinnamon and nutmeg lingering.

2014. One of my earliest good beer experiences in 2010. Anyway enough nostalgia. This is a little over spiced, or under malted. Either way it’s trying to be bold without any trousers on. It’s still great though, just a little more booze and something to tame and have a comforting hand on the shoulder. Nice lacing.

Brownish frothy medium head, diminishing.

Redish dark brown. Clear medium body.
Taste is roasted malt, spicy (cinnamon, ginger), citric, prune.

Aftertaste is slightly acid with dry bitterness.

Amazing head retention! very dark porter brown color. First impression of a bitter vanilla bean, not in bad way. Almost a smoky vanilla. Also good medium/full body hops are earthy and a hint of spruce or pine finish. Not a lot of aroma some malt aroma.

ENG: 12fl. oz. from Liquor Mart in Winnipeg, poured into a glass. I am drinking a "Happy New Year 2014" labeled version, which have "best before" date 11/2016, looks strange, but maybe that’s the real such long term. Color is very dark brown - almost black, very clean. There was just a little yellow-brownish head which disappeared at once. No saturation. Very sweet aroma of ginger and caramel malts. In turn, cloves are most present in taste, but also spices, ginger and malt, with hint of champagne alcohol and maybe sweet coffee in the background. Some mild caramel/roasty bitter aftertaste - very nice, not arrears. This beer is not fascinating, but it’s decent. The aromas and taste are mild, and maybe that’s due to the 2014 version (so one year old). /////~~~~~///// !!! /////~~~~~///// PL: Butelka 12fl. oz. kupiona w Liquor Mart w Winnipeg, przelana do szkła. Jest to wersja z etykietą "Happy New Year 2014" z datą przydatności 11/2016, co wydaje mi się dość dziwne, ale może rzeczywiście to piwo ma tak długi termin przydatności. Kolor jest bardzo ciemno brązowy, niemal czarny z delikatnymi prześwitami. Bardzo klarowny. Piana ciemnożółto-beżowa, podczas nalewania ledwo się utworzyła i szybko zniknęła. Znikome nasycenie. Bardzo słodki aromat imbiru oraz karmelu. Z kolei w smaku zdecydowanie bardziej daje się odczuć goździki, później imbir i inne przyprawy, słodycz, z domieszką szampana / alkoholu, może nawet słodkiej kawy gdzieś w tle. Lekka goryczka karmelowo / palona w posmaku - przyjemna, nie zalegająca. Niestety to piwo nie zrobiło na mnie jakiegoś szczególnego wrażenia, jakiego spodziewałem się po piwie tego typu. Niemniej jednak piwo jest pijalne, delikatne. Aromaty i smak były bardzo dleikatne, co może mieć znaczenie, jeśli ta butelka faktycznie jest z przed roku (co można wywnioskować po etykiecie z 2014).

Transfer from BA review on 12-2-12-

 Poured from bottle into pint glass

 Appearance – The beer is poured a brown color with reddish hues shinning through. A huge tan head is present upon pouring. It has great retention, eventually fading to give a good level of lacing.

 Smell – The aroma is sweet of cherry and some roasted brown bread aromas. Mixed with these aromas are spices of cinnamon and nutmeg with a god dose of pine hop. Rounding it all out is a light nut smell.

 Taste –The taste begins with a roasted brown bread and light nut taste with a very small amount of toffee sweetness. A light dark fruit soon replaces the toffee. While the sweet taste changes, overall the sweet remains light throughout the taste. More roast flavors develop at the middle of the taste. These combined with an increasing spicy taste of cinnamon and nutmeg. At the end a good presence of pine and earthy hop come to the tongue. These create a green hop taste to linger on the tongue which mix with the spice and roast flavors to leave a slightly bitter roasted flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel – The body is a on the slightly thicker side with a carbonation level that is on the lower side. They are rather good for the hop, roasted, and spice flavors of the brew and while only at 5.5 % make it more of a sipper then traditional brews of similar strength.

 Overall – Not a bad more bitter and roasty winter ale. While I traditionally prefer something with a little more sweetness in a winter warmer, this beer has a nice blend of flavors and feel which are nice for the drier tastes.

Bona cervesa, bastant equilibrada i gustosa.
Buena cerveza, bastante equilibrada y sabrosa.
Botlle 33cl. Pours reddish dark brown with thick tan head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of spices and hops.

The pour produced a tall thick and creamy meringue like head. It was light tan in color and long lasting which made for lots of sticky lacing on the glass. Under the head lies a very deep dark liquid with dark burgundy hues. It has a nice aroma of nutty roasted malt with spices like clove and nutmeg. There is a firm hop presence as well that adds a spruce like pine character. There is a solid roasted barley and mildly sweet bready/nutty maltiness with a pleasant level of clove and nutmeg spice notes. This complemented and balanced by mellow hop bitterness and flavor notes of fresh cut spruce pine. The spice and piney notes linger on well into the slow fading finish.

Anchor Christmas 2011: Sötét, barnásvörös színe van a tetején egy vastag, krémes és szűnni nem akaró, bézs színű habpaplannal, valamint fás, pörkölt és enyhén füstös aromája. Igen intenzív pörkölésű, határozottan füstös és erősen komlós ízvilág jellemzi, melyet megtámogat egy réteg étcsokoládé bársonyos jelenléte is. 

Anchor Our Special Ale 2013: A 2011-es verzióban emlékezetem szerint a pörkölt malátás jelleg domborodott ki, az idei főzet azonban már a fűszeres jegyek jelenlététől hangos mind illatában, mind ízében. Talán csak a színe maradt változatlan, egyébként pedig egy gyönyörű téli köntösbe öltöztetett, ánizsos illatokkal megspékelt, kerekded és édeskés, bársonyosan sima medvecukros zamatokkal átitatott itallá vált az idei évre.
A nice winter ale with deep and complex flavours of nutmeg, other spices, raisins and more. While enjoyable, not a beer I would have many of in one sitting, but would have many of in many sittings.

The Anchor Merry Christmas, Happy New Year pours a dark brown color with a frothy tan brown head that doesn’t linger too long. The aroma features a lovely mixture of raisin, cranberries, cinnamon and pine. The flavor is cranberry, cinnamon, pine and molasses. Overall this is a very solid brew.
Botella de 35,5 cl, adquirida en Cerveceria Internacional. Color ambar oscuro. Sabor a malta, caramelo, afrutado, herbal y dulce.

Bottle. Obviously a bit of difference between the vintages, but the general impression is more or less the same year after year. Pours dark amber with a finger thick off white head. Aroma is roasted malts and caramel and cocoa, as well as a herby symphony of cloves, juniper, cardamom and sweet Christmas bread. Full body with soft carbonation. Flavour is sweet, with dark roasted malts, cocoa, coffee and kandi, as well as herby anise and cloves giving a long spicy finish.
Pours a nice dark brown color with tan head. Dark fruit, spice, and some fig on the nose; all follow onto the palate. Finishes with some sweetness. A good winter warming beer.

2005 bottle, opened solo in 2014. Why do I do this to myself ? ffs. Puts deep molasses brown. Obviously no head. Aromas of fig, brown sugar, dark fruits. Taste is thin, slightly oxidized, but surprisingly flavorful. Fruit, Brian sugar, lightly bitter. A bit of wood and maple syrup. Not bad for a decade old almost.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a nice dark red-brown with a four inch tan head. Taste is of roasted malt, caramel, fruit, prunes, spice, pine and hops. Lots of flavor. Deep aroma that is similar. Has a decent body. Very easy to drink and incredibly enjoyable.
Aroma of malt, dark fruits, spices such as clove, nutmeg, cinnamon, you name it. Flavour is very herbal and sweet. I’m generally not a big fan of spicy winter ales, but this one is alright.

Black pour with inch of healthy beige head. Aroma of belgian yeast and blue spruce and cherry, pine hops and cream too, toffee, coriander, cinnamon, angostura bitters. Overall a creamy, boch-y beer aroma with cherry or banana. Lively carbonation, leaves teeth filmy/dry. Flavor is strange, definite strong syrupy pine/spruce, sour, malty chocolate too, cinnamon and coriander. Richteous and compelling beer.

about as perfect a beer for me as you could get. especially when aged a few years, this beer is in my top 5. what can i say? the dark fruit and spice of this is awesome. mulled wine and nutmeg aroma with a body that tastes a lot like plum, dark cherry, cinnamon and sugar. just the right bitterness to balance. this beer ages very well and the aging will mellow out the piney bitterness and let more of the dark fruit flavors come through.

Bottle from Csak a Jó Sör. 2013 edition. Aroma raisins, plum, cola. Interesting. Clear dark brown colour. Taste is intensely spicy. Tart sourish spruce, dirt, clove, light cinnamon. Does not work very well with me.

pours hazy almost cloudy brown, red tint, with a small light beige head showing some retention and lacing. caramel and nutty/fruity maltiness, coriander, aniseed, cinnamno, coffee, other bitter herbs - sort of like a popular italian bitter liquor, fruitiness - cherries and other berries, hint of sweetness. moderate carbonation, light body - oily, dry bitter grassy-earthy-peppery-very spicy finish. o-k.

355ml. Bottle. 2013

Pours dark ruby brown with tan head. 

Aroma raisin, dark fruits, spice, toffee, cinnamon. 

Taste fruity sweet, some bitters. 

Mouthfeel bit creamy. 

Nice brew.

2013 merry Christmas and happy new year brew.

pours a dark mahogany with a very large khaki head, and good lacing.

smell is of spice, malt, toffee, and dark fruit.

taste is sour, malt, spice, and some hops. ends tart and slightly bitter.

Barwa: brązowa, pod światło rubinowa. Piana kremowa, początkowo obfita, drobno pęcherzykowa, oblepiająca szkło. Wysycenie średnie. 

Aromat: wreszcie aromat piwa świątecznego - słodki i przyprawowy. Wyczuwalny cynamon i goździki, choć browar zaprzecza, że ich używa. Obecne także karmel, pierniki i ciemne słody. Zdecydowanie przyjemny. 

Smak: raczej niezbyt pełny. Gorzka czekolada, pierniki, przyprawy, spieczone ciasto, lekka goryczka. O dziwo praktycznie nie słodki, wytrawny. 

Anchor Christmas Ale pojawia się cyklicznie od 1975 roku. Tajny jest jego skład, który zmienia się corocznie, podobnie, jak etykieta (zawsze zdobi ją drzewo - niekoniecznie świąteczne). Zmienna jest również zawartość alkoholu. W tym roku piwo nie jest zbyt mocne i przekłada się to na smak. Nie spodziewajcie się zatem tutaj jakiejś bomby czy eksplozji smaków, bowiem jest ono raczej zbalansowane. Dla mnie brakuje trochę ciała i słodyczy, ponieważ tak wyobrażam sobie piwa świąteczne. To moja pierwsze podejście do Anchor - Christmas Ale i mimo pewnych zastrzeżeń chętnie spróbowałbym go w przyszłym roku w kolejnej wersji.
Dunkelbraunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr röstmalzig, winterliche Gewürze. Geschmack röstmalzig süß, Karamell, Gewürze.

Bottle poured a clear brown hue w/ a large frothy tan head. Moderate to bold spicy aromas. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ a light bitter finish. Tastes are vanilla, rye, malts, and Grahm cracker. Medium bodied w/ a dry tanin finish.
Bottle, pours a really dark brown. Spiced up aroma. Tastes of xmas spices, notably cinnamon and ginger, some bitterness on the back end.
